title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: Install latest stable version CRAN: can also install development version Rdpack Github:
code: install.packages("Rdpack") library(devtools) install_github("GeoBosh/Rdpack")

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: simplest way insert Bibtex references Rd macro \insertRef. Just put \insertRef{key}{package} documentation insert item key key file REFERENCES.bib package package. Alternatively, use one \insertCite{key}{package} commands cite works REFERENCES.bib, issue single \insertAllCited{} directive produce list cited references. work DESCRIPTION file package needs amended, see full details.

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: prepare package importing BibTeX references necessary tell package management tools package Rdpack Rd macros needed. references put file inst/REFERENCES.bib. steps enumerated somewhat detail, see also vignette Inserting_bibtex_references. Add following lines file “DESCRIPTION”: Make sure capitalisation RdMacros: shown. field RdMacros: already present, add “Rdpack” list line. Similarly field “Imports:”. Add following line file “NAMESPACE”: equivalent line roxygen2 Create file REFERENCES.bib subdirectory inst/ package put BibTeX references .
code: Imports: Rdpack RdMacros: Rdpack importFrom(Rdpack,reprompt) #' @importFrom Rdpack reprompt

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: steps outlined done, references can inserted documentation key bibtex key reference package package. works Rd files roxygen documentation chunks. Usually references put section references. Rd file might look something like: equivalent roxygen2 documentation chunk : first line inserts reference key Rpackage:rbibutils Rdpack’s REFERENCES.bib. second line inserts reference labeled R file REFERENCES.bib package bibtex. example demonstrates references packages can inserted (case bibtex), well. strongly discouraged released versions convenient development. One relatively safe use package also - allows authors multiple packages copy refences packages. details see vignette Inserting_bibtex_references open R: (latest version vignette Inserting_bibtex_references (development version github).)
code: \insertRef{key}{package} \references{ \insertRef{Rdpack:bibtex}{Rdpack}  \insertRef{R}{bibtex} } #' @references #' \insertRef{Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack} #' #' \insertRef{R}{bibtex} vignette("Inserting_bibtex_references", package = "Rdpack")

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: Additional Rd macros available citations. can used Rd roxygen2 documentation. \insertCite{key}{package} cites key records use \insertAllCited, see . key can contain keys separated commas. \insertCite{parseRd,Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack} produces (Murdoch 2010; Boshnakov Putman 2020) \insertCite{Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack} gives (Boshnakov Putman 2020). default citations parenthesised: \insertCite{parseRd}{Rdpack} produces (Murdoch 2010). get textual citations, like Murdoch (2010), put string ;textual end key. references last two sentences produced \insertCite{parseRd}{Rdpack} \insertCite{parseRd;textual}{Rdpack}, respectively. also works several citations, e.g. \insertCite{parseRd,Rpackage:rbibutils;textual}{Rdpack} produces: Murdoch (2010); Boshnakov Putman (2020). macro \insertNoCite{key}{package} records one references \insertAllCited cite . Setting key * include references specified package. example, \insertNoCite{R}{bibtex} \insertNoCite{*}{utils} record specified references inclusion \insertAllCited. \insertAllCited inserts references cited \insertCite \insertNoCite. Putting macro references section keep date automatically. Rd section may look something like: , roxygen2, references chunk might look like : Don’t align backslash second ‘e’ @references, since roxygen2 may interpret verbatim text, macro. mix citations text, ``see also’’ ``chapter 3’’, write list keys free text, starting symbol @ prefixing key . @ symbol appear output. example, following code produces: (see also Murdoch 2010 Boshnakov Putman 2020) (see also Murdoch 2010; Boshnakov Putman 2020) see also Murdoch (2010) Boshnakov Putman (2020) parenthesised citations, need markup text citations, say see also italic, put ;nobrackets end first argument Rd macro, take part containing markup, put parentheses suitable. example, (markdown, use _see also_ place \emph{see also}). gives: (see also Murdoch 2010 Boshnakov Putman 2020) — \insertCiteOnly{key}{package} \insertCite include key list references \insertAllCited.
code: \insertAllCited{} #' @references #'   \insertAllCited{} \insertCite{@see also @parseRd and @Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack} \insertCite{@see also @parseRd; @Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack} \insertCite{@see also @parseRd and @Rpackage:rbibutils;textual}{Rdpack} (\emph{see also} \insertCite{@@parseRd and @Rpackage:rbibutils;nobrackets}{Rdpack})

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: Bibliography styles lists references supported Rdpack (>= 0.8). Currently alternative offered use long names (Georgi N. Boshnakov) place default style (Boshnakov GN). comprehensive alternatives can included needed requested. cause lists references produced \insertAllCited package appear full names, add .onLoad() function package. don’t .onLoad(), just copy following definition: already .onLoad(), add line containing Rdpack::Rdpack_bibstyles call . installling/reloading package lists references appear long author names. “Rdpack” now uses style.
code: .onLoad <- function(lib, pkg){     Rdpack::Rdpack_bibstyles(package = pkg, authors = "LongNames")     invisible(NULL) }

what: A puzzling message in devtools development mode
title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: described procedure works transparently roxygen2 chunks Hadley Wickham’s package devtools. Packages built installed properly devtools commands references processed expected. Currently (2017-08-04) run help commands ?xxx functions package working developement mode help pages contain references, may encounter puzzling warning messages, something like: warnings harmless can ignored — help pages built properly warnings appear outside developer’s mode, e.g. separate R session1. Even better, use function viewRd() described view required help file.
code: 1: In tools::parse_Rd(path) :   ~/mypackage/man/abcde.Rd: 67: unknown macro '\insertRef'

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: functions underlying processing references citations intercept errors, missing BibTeX labels badly formed items REFERENCES.bib, issue informative warnings building installation package, developer alerted package can still built installed. cases functions usually insert suitable text documentation, well. encounter situation contradicting description, probably bug — please report (check first typical errors listed ). non-decipherable error message probably caused one following typical errors: misspelled RdMacros: field file DESCRIPTION. safest way avoid copy DESCRIPTION file working package. omitted second argument reference citation macro. macros package name second argument. errors occur parsing Rd files, control passed Rdpack’s macros.

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: principle, BibTeX entries may contain arbitrary Latex markup, Rd format supports subset. consequence, BibTeX entries may need editing included REFERENCES.bib2. entries render properly cause errors, since time necessary. mathematics doesn’t render properly replace Latex dollar syntax Rd’s \eqn, e.g. $x^2$ \eqn{x^2}. needed versions Rdpack 0.8-4 later. Latex macros may removed replaced suitable Rd markup. , cause problems, since supported, e.g. \doi. See also overview help page, help("Rdpack-package"), package "Rdpack". Among things, contains dummy references illustrate .

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: package declared encoding (file DESCRIPTION), REFERENCES.bib read-encoding3. Otherwise, encoding REFERENCES.bib assumed UTF-8 (includes ASCII subset). Note BibTeX entries downloaded online databases similar sources may contain unexpected characters encodings, e.g. ‘latin1’. cases check tools R-devel (since 2018-10-01) may give warnings like: resolve , convert file declared encoding UTF-8. Alternatively, replace offending symbols classic TeX/LaTeX equivalents (ASCII). Non-ASCII symbols BibTeX entries obtained online databases often fields like “Abstract”, normally included lists references can deleted REFERENCES.bib. One way check non-ASCII symbols file tools::showNonASCIIfile(). Internally, LaTeX sequences standing accented Latin characters, \'e \"o, converted UTF-8. , even file REFERENCES.bib pure ASCII, may implicitly give raise non-ASCII characters. may cause R’s checking tools complain non-ASCII characters even verified none. happens, add encoding declaration file DESCRIPTION4: Needless say, make sure really characters encodings like ‘latin1’.
code: prepare_Rd: input string 1 is invalid in this locale Encoding: UTF-8

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: function, viewRd(), view Rd files source directory package introduced version 0.4-23 Rdpack. typical user call look something like: default requested help page shown text format. open page browser, set argument ‘type’ “html”: viewRd() renders references citations correctly, since understands Rd macros. Users ‘devtools’ can use viewRd place help() view rendered Rd sources development mode. work also development mode platform (e.g. RStudio, Emacs/ESS, Rgui).
code: Rdpack::viewRd("./man/filename.Rd") Rdpack::viewRd("./man/filename.Rd", type = "html")

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: Rdpack::reprompt() updates Rd documentation. common case called Rd file, updates documentation functions, methods classes documented file. functions includes updating usage section, adding missing aliases \item’s arguments described yet. methods classes entries new methods slots updated similar way. See documentation details. Rdpack::reprompt() can also invoked object name object, just utils::prompt. case checks installed documentation object works found. Otherwise creates Rd file initial content similar one generated utils::prompt modified package can built. new function, say newfun documented existing Rd file, just add newfun() usage section file call Rdpack::reprompt() insert correct usage statement, add alias, add items new arguments. Put quotes around function name non-syntactic. replacement functions (functions names ending <-) reprompt() insert proper usage statement. example, signature xxx<- (x, ..., value), , "xxx<-"() xxx() <- value replaced xxx(x, ...) <- value. Rdpack::reprompt() remove anything become obsolete alerts user remove aliases, methods, descriptions arguments removed.

what: Reprompt and open in an editor
title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: open reprompt()-ed file, argument edit can used. work, options("editor") needs set suitably usually . edit = TRUE, Rdpack::reprompt() open Rd file editor. convenient access feature, use Rdpack::ereprompt() (edit reprompt), calls Rdpack::reprompt() edit = TRUE sets output filename input filename. RStudio, reprompt() can invoked Rd file edited selected name object source code file using RStudio add-Repropmpt (contributed Duncan Murdoch). Obviously, makes sense Rd files generated roxygen2. Emacs/ESS various ways use Rdpack::reprompt() Rdpack::ereprompt(). options("editor") set emacsclient, Rdpack::ereprompt one option. can also assigned key (wrapped Elisp code), example invoked currently edited file. function example key binding can found georgisemacs.

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: Rdpack provides macro takes chunk R code, evaluates , includes code results rendered documentation. layout similar R console code prefixed anything output prefixed comment symbols. example, gives help page ?Rdpack::promptUsage contains number examples created \printExample. corresponding Rd file can obtained package tarball https://github.com/GeoBosh/Rdpack/blob/master/man/promptUsage.Rd. Vignette Inserting_figures_and_evaluated_examples gives details.

what: Evaluating the examples in section Examples
title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: macro \runExamples can used replacement section examples. example, following code put top level Rd file (.e. section): evaluated replaced normal section examples: generated examples section processed standard R tools (almost) outset. particular, examples run R’s quality control tools tangled along examples documentation files5. small example package using feature runExamplesCheck.
code: \runExamples{2+2; a <- 2*3; a} \examples{ 2 + 2 ##: 4 a <- 2 * 3 a ##: 6 }

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: Figures can inserted help standard Rd markup command \figure. generate figures fly, package "Rdpack" provides Rd macro \insertFig takes snipped R code, evaluates inserts plot produced (using \figure). \insertFig takes three arguments: filename, package name code evaluate produce figure. example, evaluate code, save graph file "man/figures/cars.png" subdirectory package "mypackage", include figure using \figure. See vignette Inserting_figures_and_evaluated_examples details.
code: \insertFig{cars.png}{mypackage}{x <- cars$speed; y <- cars$dist; plot(x,y)}

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects
text: Versions Rdpack Github almost always fully functional (least passing R CMD check ---cran), use three-part version number. version really unstable, use conventional fourth part .9000. release CRAN, version incremented x.x.06. Note Rdpack (>= x.x.0) required, can abbreviated Rdpack (>= x.x).

title: Manipulate a number of Rd files — Rd_combo
code: if (FALSE) { rdnames <- dir(path = "./man", pattern=".*[.]Rd$", full.names=TRUE)  ## which Rd files don't have a value section? counts <- unlist(Rd_combo(rdnames, function(x) length(Rdo_locate_core_section(x, "\value")))) rdnames[counts == 0]  ## reprompt all files Rd_combo(rdnames, reprompt) for(nam in rdnames) try(reprompt(nam)) for(nam in rdnames) try(reprompt(nam, sec_copy=FALSE)) }

title: Apply a function over an Rd object — Rdapply
text: Rdapply works like rapply preserves attributes   x (recursively) sublists .  Rdapply   first calls rapply, passing arguments .   restores recursively attributes calling rattr. Note object returned rapply assumed   identical structure original object. means argument   rapply must "unlist" normally   "replace".  Rdtagapply gives sensible default values   classes .  See documentation   rapply details possible choices   classes, arguments passed via   "\dots". Rdtagapply convenience variant Rdapply   common task modifying examining elements given   Rd_tag attribute. Since Rd equation macros \eqn   \deqn assigned Rd tag "VERB" processed differently   "VERB" pieces,  pseudo-tags   "mathVERB" "nonmathVERB" provided, "mathVERB"   actions first argument mathematical macros \eqn   \deqn, "nonmathVERB" actions "VERB" macros   contexts. also pseudo-tag "nonmath" anything   math. rattr auxilliary function takes two Rd objects   (identical structure) recursively examines . makes   attributes lists first argument identical   corresponding attributes second.

title: Apply a function over an Rd object — Rdapply
code:
# create an Rd object for the sake of example u1 <- list_Rd(name = "Dummyname", alias = "dummyfun",               title = "Dummy title", description = "Dummy description",               usage = "dummyfun(x)",               value = "numeric vector",               author = "A. Author",               examples = "
a <- matrix(1:6,nrow=2)
a %*% t(a)
t(a) %*% a",               Rd_class=TRUE )  # correct R code for examples but wrong for saving in Rd files Rdo_show(u1)  # escape percents everywhere except in comments #  (actually, .anypercent escapes only unescaped percents) rdo <- Rdapply(u1, Rdpack:::.anypercent, classes = "character", how = "replace")  # syntactically wrong R code for examples but ok for saving in Rd files Rdo_show(rdo)   # Rdo2Rdf does this by default for examples and other R code, #   so code can be kept syntactically correct while processing. #   (reprompt() takes care of this too as it uses Rdo2Rdf for saving)  fn <- tempfile("u1", fileext="Rd") Rdo2Rdf(u1, file = fn) #> 	The Rd content was written to file  /var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/u17a81ea11780Rd   # the saved file contains escaped percents but they disappear in parsing: file.show(fn) Rdo_show(tools::parse_Rd(fn))  # if you think that sections should start on new lines, # the following makes the file a little more human-friendly #   (by inserting new lines). # todo: additional arg. for list_Rd for this?  u2 <- Rdpack:::.Rd_tidy(u1) Rdo2Rdf(u2, file = fn) #> 	The Rd content was written to file  /var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/u17a81ea11780Rd  file.show(fn)  unlink(fn)

code: ## the following creates Rd object rdo dummyfun <- function(x) x fn <- tempfile("dummyfun", fileext = ".Rd") reprompt(dummyfun, filename = fn) #> Rd source not supplied, looking for installed documentation. #> Rd source not supplied and installed documentation not found. #> Trying a 'prompt' function to generate documentation for the object. #> Error in reprompt(dummyfun, filename = fn): unsuccessful attempt to create Rd doc. using a 'prompt' function. rdo <- tools::parse_Rd(fn) #> Warning: cannot open file '/var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/dummyfun7a87f4327be.Rd': No such file or directory #> Error in file(con, "r"): cannot open the connection  ## add documentation for arguments ## that are not in the signature of 'dummyfun()' dottext <- "further arguments to be passed on." dots <- paste0("\\", "dots") rdo2 <- Rdo_append_argument(rdo, dots, dottext, create = TRUE) #> Error in Rdo_modify(rdo, wrk, create = TRUE): object 'rdo' not found rdo2 <- Rdo_append_argument(rdo2, "z", "a numeric vector") #> Error in Rdo_modify(rdo, wrk, create = TRUE): object 'rdo2' not found  ## reprompt() warns to remove documentation for non-existing arguments: Rdo_show(reprompt(rdo2, filename = fn)) #> Error in reprompt(rdo2, filename = fn): object 'rdo2' not found  unlink(fn)

title: Collect aliases or other metadata from an Rd object — Rdo_collect_aliases
code: ## this example originally (circa 2012) was: ##     infile <- file.path(R.home(), "src/library/base/man/timezones.Rd") ## but the OS conditional alias in that file has been removed. ## So, create an artificial example: infile <- system.file("examples", "tz.Rd", package = "Rdpack")  ## file.show(infile) rd <- tools::parse_Rd(infile)  ## The functions described here handle "ifdef" and similar directives. ## This detects OS specific aliases (windows = "onlywin" and unix = "onlyunix"): Rdo_collect_aliases(rd) #>                                     windows       unix  #>       "a1"       "a2"       "a3"  "onlywin" "onlyunix"  Rdpack:::Rdo_collect_metadata(rd, "alias") # same #>                                     windows       unix  #>       "a1"       "a2"       "a3"  "onlywin" "onlyunix"   ## In contrast, the following do not find "onlywin" and "onlyunix": sapply(rd[which(tools:::RdTags(rd)=="\alias")], as.character) #> list() tools:::.Rd_get_metadata(rd, "alias") #> [1] "a1" "a2" "a3"  Rdpack:::Rdo_collect_metadata(rd, "name") #>             #> "dummyfun"  Rdpack:::Rdo_collect_metadata(rd, "keyword") #>              #> "kw1" "kw2"

title: Get the labels of items in an Rd object — Rdo_get_item_labels
code: infile <- system.file("examples", "tz.Rd", package = "Rdpack") rd <- tools::parse_Rd(infile)  ## get item labels found anywhere in the Rd object (items <- Rdo_get_item_labels(rd)) #> [1] "x"           "y"           "type"        "flag"        "res"         #> [6] "convergence"  ## search only in section "arguments" (i.e., get argument names) ## (note [[1]] - there is only one arguments section) pos.args <- Rdo_locate_core_section(rd, "\\arguments")[[1]] (args <- Rdo_get_item_labels(rd[[pos.args$pos]])) #> [1] "x"    "y"    "type" "flag"  ## search only in section "value" pos.val <- Rdo_locate_core_section(rd, "\\value")[[1]] (vals <- Rdo_get_item_labels(rd[[pos.val$pos]])) #> [1] "res"         "convergence"  ## There are no other items in 'rd', so this gives TRUE: all.equal(items, c(args, vals)) # TRUE #> [1] TRUE

title: Replace or modify parts of Rd objects — Rdo_modify

title: Replace or modify parts of Rd objects — Rdo_modify
text: Argument rdo Rd object (complete fragment)   modified. val Rd fragment use modification. Basically, val appended (replace FALSE)   replaces (replace TRUE) content element   rdo "Rd_tag" val. Argument top specifies whether check "Rd_tag"   rdo , see . details. top TRUE rdo val   (non-NULL) "Rd_tag", action depends replace   (argument create ignored case).   replace TRUE, val returned. Otherwise   rdo val , effectively, concatenated. example,   rdo may "arguments" section Rd object   val may also "arguments" section containing new   arguments. Otherwise, element "Rd_tag" val searched   rdo using tools:::RdTags(). elements found,   action depends replace.  replace character string, first element     rdo list whose element identical     value replace replaced val.     element present create TRUE, val     inserted rdo. create FALSE, rdo     changed. replace TRUE, first element found replaced     val. replace FALSE, val appended first     element found. element "Rd_tag" val found action   depends create.  create TRUE, val   inserted rdo, effectively creating new section.   create FALSE, error thrown. Rdo_replace_section like Rdo_modify argument   top fixed TRUE default argument replace   set TRUE. hardly makes sense call Rdo_replace_section   replace = FALSE  character value may   handy cases, see examples.

code: # the following creates Rd object rdo dummyfun <- function(x) x fn <- tempfile("dummyfun", fileext = "Rd")  reprompt(dummyfun, filename = fn) #> Rd source not supplied, looking for installed documentation. #> Rd source not supplied and installed documentation not found. #> Trying a 'prompt' function to generate documentation for the object. #> Error in reprompt(dummyfun, filename = fn): unsuccessful attempt to create Rd doc. using a 'prompt' function. rdo <- tools::parse_Rd(fn) #> Warning: cannot open file '/var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/dummyfun7a826dd0437Rd': No such file or directory #> Error in file(con, "r"): cannot open the connection  dottext <- "further arguments to be passed on."  dots <- paste0("\\", "dots") rdo2 <- Rdo_append_argument(rdo, dots, dottext, create = TRUE) #> Error in Rdo_modify(rdo, wrk, create = TRUE): object 'rdo' not found rdo2 <- Rdo_append_argument(rdo2, "z", "a numeric vector") #> Error in Rdo_modify(rdo, wrk, create = TRUE): object 'rdo2' not found  Rdo_show(Rdo_reparse(rdo2)) #> Error in Rdo2Rdf(rdo, file = outfile): object 'rdo2' not found  # the following does ot show the arguments. (todo: why?) #    (see also examples in Rdo_append_argument) Rdo_show(rdo2) #> Error in prepare_Rd(Rd, defines = defines, stages = stages, fragment = fragment,     ...): object 'rdo2' not found  unlink(fn)

text: Rdo_sections locates sections top level Rd   object. includes predefined sections user defined   sections. Sections wrapped #ifdef directives also found. Rdo_sections returns list one entry section   rdo. entry list components "pos"   "title" giving position (suitable use "[[")   title section.  user defined sections actual   name returned, "section". names sections returned single strings without   attributes. titles predefined sections single words   user defined sections may longer titles sometimes contain   basic markup. Rdo_locate_core_section works similarly returns   results section sec. Currently simply calls   Rdo_sections returns results sec. Note consistency Rdo_locate_core_section   attempt simplify result common case   one instance requested section---put list length   one. (Murdoch 2010)      (Francois 2014)

code: infile <- system.file("examples", "tz.Rd", package = "Rdpack") rd <- tools::parse_Rd(infile)  ## Locate all top level sections in rd sections <- Rdo_sections(rd) ## How many sections there are in rd? length(sections) #> [1] 16 ## What are their titles? sapply(sections, function(x) x$title) #>  [1] "\\name"              "\\alias"             "\\alias"             #>  [4] "\\alias"             "\\alias"             "\\alias"             #>  [7] "\\title"             "\\description"       "\\usage"             #> [10] "\\arguments"         "\\details"           "\\value"             #> [13] "Further information" "\\examples"          "\\keyword"           #> [16] "\\keyword"            ## The names of builtin sections include the backslash Rdo_locate_core_section(rd, "\\title") #> [[1]] #> [[1]]$pos #> [1] 11 #>  #> [[1]]$title #> [1] "\\title" #>  #>   ## Locate a user defined secion Rdo_locate_core_section(rd, "Further information") #> [[1]] #> [[1]]$pos #> [1] 23 #>  #> [[1]]$title #> [1] "Further information" #>  #>   ## The names of builtin sections include the backslash Rdo_locate_core_section(rd, "\\details") #> [[1]] #> [[1]]$pos #> [1] 19 #>  #> [[1]]$title #> [1] "\\details" #>  #>   ## All appearances of the requested section are returned Rdo_locate_core_section(rd, "\\alias") #> [[1]] #> [[1]]$pos #> [1] 3 #>  #> [[1]]$title #> [1] "\\alias" #>  #>  #> [[2]] #> [[2]]$pos #> [1] 5 #>  #> [[2]]$title #> [1] "\\alias" #>  #>  #> [[3]] #> [[3]]$pos #> [1] 7 #>  #> [[3]]$title #> [1] "\\alias" #>  #>  #> [[4]] #> [[4]]$pos #> [1] 9 2 1 #>  #> [[4]]$title #> [1] "\\alias" #>  #>  #> [[5]] #> [[5]]$pos #> [1] 10  2  1 #>  #> [[5]]$title #> [1] "\\alias" #>  #>  Rdo_locate_core_section(rd, "\\keyword") #> [[1]] #> [[1]]$pos #> [1] 27 #>  #> [[1]]$title #> [1] "\\keyword" #>  #>  #> [[2]] #> [[2]]$pos #> [1] 29 #>  #> [[2]]$title #> [1] "\\keyword" #>  #>

title: Update and Manipulate Rd Documentation Objects — Rdpack-package
code: ## The examples below show typical use but are not executable. ## For executable examples see the help pages of  ## reprompt, promptPackageSexpr, and rebib.  ## To make the examples executable, replace "myfun" with a real ## function, and similarly for classes and paths to files.  if (FALSE) { ## update the doc. from the Rd source and save myfun.Rd ##     in the current directory (like prompt) reprompt(infile="path/to/mypackage/man/myfun.Rd")  ## update doc of myfun() from the installed doc (if any); ##     if none is found, create it like prompt reprompt("myfun") reprompt(myfun)      # same  ## update doc. for S4 methods from Rd source reprompt(infile="path/to/mypackage/man/myfun-methods.Rd")  ## update doc. for S4 methods from installed doc (if any); ##     if none is found, create it like promptMethods reprompt("myfun", type = "methods") reprompt("myfun-methods")  # same   ## update doc. for S4 class from Rd source reprompt(infile="path/to/mypackage/man/myclass-class.Rd")  ## update doc. of S4 class from installed doc. ##     if none is found, create it like promptClass reprompt("myclass-class") reprompt("myclass", type = "class")  # same   ## create a skeleton "mypackage-package.Rd" promptPackageSexpr("mypackage")  ## update the references in "mypackage-package.Rd" rebib(infile="path/to/mypackage/man/mypackage-package.Rd", force=TRUE) }

title:
Add content to the element of an Rd object or fragment at a given
  position — append_to_Rd_list
text: element  rdo position pos replaced   concatenation x. result keeps "Rd_tag"   rdo[[pos]]. Argument pos may specify position depth Rd   object. function relatively low level mainly use   functions.

#rdoseq <- utils:::.getHelpFile(help("seq")) rdoseq <- Rdo_fetch("seq", "base") iusage <- which(tools:::RdTags(rdoseq) == "\usage") iusage #> [1] 10 attr(rdoseq[[iusage]], "Rd_tag") #> [1] "\usage"  ## append a new line after the last usage line rdoseq2 <- append_to_Rd_list(rdoseq, list(Rdo_newline()), iusage)  ## Suppose that we wish to describe the function 'sequence' in the same Rd file. ## We append an usage statement for 'sequence()', without worrying about its ## actual signature. rdoseq2 <- append_to_Rd_list(rdoseq2, list(Rdo_Rcode("sequence()")), iusage) Rdo_show(rdoseq2)  ## the two operations can be done in one step rdoseq3 <- append_to_Rd_list(rdoseq, list(Rdo_newline(), Rdo_Rcode("sequence()")), iusage) Rdo_show(rdoseq3)  ## now run reprompt() to update rdoseq3, namely: ##    (1) it corrects the signature of 'sequence' in section \usage. ##    (2) reports new argument "nvec" ##    (3) inserts \item for the new argument(s) in section \arguments. reprompt(rdoseq3, Concatenate Rd objects or pieces — c_Rd
text: ... objects concatenated, Rd objects character     strings, see `Details'.

title: Concatenate Rd objects or pieces — c_Rd
text: arguments may mixture lists character strings.   lists typically "Rd" objects pieces. character strings may   also elements "Rd" objects carrying "Rd_tag" attributes.   "Rd_tag" attribute character strings missing set   "TEXT". Finally, character element "\dots"   enclosed list. Eventually arguments become lists concatenated using   c(). arguments class "Rd", class   result set "Rd". Otherwise, "Rd_tag" result set   first () non-null "Rd_tag" arguments. structure "Rd" objects described   Murdoch (2010) .

title: Concatenate Rd objects or pieces — c_Rd
text: Rd object list whose attribute "Rd_tag" set descibed   `Details'

title: Concatenate Rd objects or pieces — c_Rd
text: Georgi N. Boshnakov

title: Concatenate Rd objects or pieces — c_Rd
text: Duncan Murdoch (2010). “Parsing Rd files.” https://developer.r-project.org/parseRd.pdf.

title: Concatenate Rd objects or pieces — c_Rd
code: a1 <- char2Rdpiece("Dummyname", "name") a2 <- char2Rdpiece("Dummyallias1", "alias") a3 <- char2Rdpiece("Dummy title", "title") a4 <- char2Rdpiece("Dummy description", "description")  ## The following are equivalent ## (gbRd::Rdo_empty() creates an empty list of class 'Rd') if(requireNamespace("gbRd")){ b1 <- c_Rd(gbRd::Rdo_empty(), list(a1), list(a2), list(a3), list(a4)) c1 <- c_Rd(gbRd::Rdo_empty(), list(a1, a2, a3, a4)) d1 <- c_Rd(gbRd::Rdo_empty(), list(a1, a2), list(a3, a4)) identical(c1, b1) identical(c1, d1) Rdo_show(b1)  ## insert a newline d1n <- c_Rd(gbRd::Rdo_empty(), list(a1, a2), Rdo_newline(), list(a3, a4)) str(d1n) } #> Loading required namespace: gbRd #> List of 5 #>  $ :List of 1 #>   ..$ : chr "Dummyname" #>   .. ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "VERB" #>   ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "\\name" #>  $ :List of 1 #>   ..$ : chr "Dummyallias1" #>   .. ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "VERB" #>   ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "\\alias" #>  $ : chr "\n" #>   ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "TEXT" #>  $ :List of 1 #>   ..$ : chr "Dummy title" #>   .. ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "TEXT" #>   ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "\\title" #>  $ :List of 1 #>   ..$ : chr "Dummy description" #>   .. ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "TEXT" #>   ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "\\description" #>  - attr(*, "class")= chr "Rd"  ## When most of the arguments are character strings ## the function 'list_Rd' may be more convenient. u1 <- list_Rd(name = "Dummyname", alias = "Dummyallias1",               title = "Dummy title", description = "Dummy description",               Rd_class = TRUE ) Rdo_show(u1)

what: Convert a character vector to Rd piece — char2Rdpiece

text: Convert character vector Rd piece.

title: Convert a character vector to Rd piece — char2Rdpiece
code: char2Rdpiece(content, name, force.sec = FALSE)

title: Convert a character vector to Rd piece — char2Rdpiece
text: content character vector. name name Rd macro, string. force.sec TRUE FALSE, see `Details'.

title: Convert a character vector to Rd piece — char2Rdpiece
text: Argument content converted Rd piece using   name determine format result. Rd tag content set appropriate name.   specifically, name name macro (without   leading `\') whose content known "Rdtag", tag   used. Otherwise tag set "TEXT". force.sec TRUE, name treated name   top level section Rd object. top level section exported   one argument macro standard section (detected   is_Rdsecname) two argument macro   "\section" otherwise. force.sec FALSE, content exported one argument   macro without checks.

title: Convert a character vector to Rd piece — char2Rdpiece
text: Georgi N. Boshnakov

title: Convert a character vector to Rd piece — char2Rdpiece
text: function attempt escape special symbols like `%'.

title: Convert a character vector to Rd piece — char2Rdpiece
code: ## add a keyword section a1 <- char2Rdpiece("graphics", "keyword") a1 #> [[1]] #> [1] "graphics" #> attr(,"Rd_tag") #> [1] "TEXT" #>  #> attr(,"Rd_tag") #> [1] "\\keyword" ## "keyword" is a standard Rd top level section, so 'force.sec' is irrelevant a2 <- char2Rdpiece("graphics", "keyword", force.sec = TRUE) identical(a1, a2) #> [1] TRUE  ## an element suitable to be put in a "usage" section char2Rdpiece("log(x, base = exp(1))", "usage") #> [[1]] #> [1] "log(x, base = exp(1))" #> attr(,"Rd_tag") #> [1] "RCODE" #>  #> attr(,"Rd_tag") #> [1] "\\usage"  ## a user defined section "Todo" char2Rdpiece("Give more examples for this function.", "Todo", force.sec = TRUE) #> [[1]] #> [[1]][[1]] #> [1] "Todo" #> attr(,"Rd_tag") #> [1] "TEXT" #>  #>  #> [[2]] #> [[2]][[1]] #> [1] "Give more examples for this function." #> attr(,"Rd_tag") #> [1] "TEXT" #>  #>  #> attr(,"Rd_tag") #> [1] "\\section"

title: Compare usage entries for a function to its actual arguments — compare_usage1

title: Compare usage entries for a function to its actual arguments — compare_usage1
text: TRUE usages identical, FALSE otherwise.   return value attribute "details", list providing   details comparison. elements list   referred name, since one urdo ucur NULL   NA, list contains fields "obj_removed", "obj_added",   "rdo_usage", "cur_usage", "alias". identical_names logical value, TRUE `name'  objects. obj_removed names present urdo ucur obj_added names present ucur urdo identical_argnames logical value,     TRUE argument names objects . identical_defaults logical value,     TRUE defaults arguments objects . identical_formals logical value, TRUE formals     , .e. fields identical_argnames     identical_defaults TRUE. added_argnames names arguments ucur urdo. removed_argnames names arguments urdo ucur. names_unchanged_defaults names arguments whose defaults . rdo_usage copy urdo. cur_usage copy ucur. alias alias name object, see `Details'.

title: Compare usage entries for a function to its actual arguments — compare_usage1

code: (a <- pairlist2f_usage1(formals(cor), "cor")) ##: name      = cor  ##: S3class   =   ##: S4sig     =   ##: infix     = FALSE  ##: fu        = TRUE  ##: argnames  = x y use method  ##: defaults  : y = NULL  ##:             use = "everything"  ##:             method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman") cat(as.character(a)) ##: cor(x, y = NULL, use = "everything",  ##:     method = c("pearson", "kendall", "spearman"))

title:
Convert f_usage objects to text appropriate for usage sections in
  Rd files — deparse_usage
text: Georgi N. Boshnakov

title:
Convert f_usage objects to text appropriate for usage sections in
  Rd files — deparse_usage
code: cur_wd <- getwd() tmpdir <- tempdir() setwd(tmpdir)  ## prepare a list of "f_usage" objects fnseq <- reprompt(seq)            # get and save the help page of "seq" #> Rd source not supplied, looking for installed documentation. #> Installed documentation found, processing it... #> 	The Rd content was written to file  seq.Rd  rdoseq <- tools::parse_Rd(fnseq)  # parse the Rd file ut <- get_usage_text(rdoseq)      # get the contents of the usage section cat(ut, "\n")                     #     of seq() (a character string) #>  #> seq(\dots) #>  #> \method{seq}{default}(from = 1, to = 1, by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1)), #>     length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, \dots) #>  #> seq.int(from, to, by, length.out, along.with, \dots) #>  #> seq_along(along.with) #> seq_len(length.out)  utp <- parse_usage_text(ut)       # parse to a list of "f_usage" objects  ## deparse the "f_usage" list - each statement gets a separate string cat(deparse_usage(utp), sep = "\n") #> seq(\dots) #> \method{seq}{default}(from = 1, to = 1, by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1)),  #>     length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, \dots) #> seq.int(from, to, by, length.out, along.with, \dots) #> seq_along(along.with) #> seq_len(length.out)  ## explore some of the usage entries individually; ## the generic seq() has a boring signature utp[[1]] #> name      = seq  #> S3class   =   #> S4sig     =   #> infix     = FALSE  #> fu        = TRUE  #> argnames  = ...  #>  as.character(utp[[1]]) #>           seq  #> "seq(\\dots)"  deparse_usage1(utp[[1]])  # same #>           seq  #> "seq(\\dots)"   ## the default S3 method is more interesting utp[[2]] #> name      = seq  #> S3class   = default  #> S4sig     =   #> infix     = FALSE  #> fu        = TRUE  #> argnames  = from to by length.out along.with ...  #> defaults  : from = 1  #>             to = 1  #>             by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1))  #>             length.out = NULL  #>             along.with = NULL  #>  cat(deparse_usage1(utp[[2]])) #> \method{seq}{default}(from = 1, to = 1, by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1)),  #>     length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, \dots) cat(as.character(utp[[2]]))   # same #> \method{seq}{default}(from = 1, to = 1, by = ((to - from)/(length.out - 1)),  #>     length.out = NULL, along.with = NULL, \dots)  unlink(fnseq) setwd(cur_wd) unlink(tmpdir)

title: Get all references from a Bibtex file — get_bibentries
code:
r <- get_bibentries(package = "Rdpack") r #> Francois R (2014). _bibtex: bibtex parser_. R package version 0.4.0. #> #> Boshnakov GN, Putman C (2020). _rbibutils: Convert Between Bibliography #> Formats_. . #> #> Murdoch D (2010). “Parsing Rd files.” https://developer.r-project.org/parseRd.pdf>. #> #> Wickham H, Hester J, Chang W (2018). _devtools: Tools to Make #> Developing R Packages Easier_. R package version 1.13.5, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=devtools>. #> #> ZZZ A (2018). “A relation between several fundamental constants: #> $e^i\pi=-1$.” _A non-existent journal with the formula $L_2$ in its #> name._. This reference does not exist. It is a test/demo that simple #> formulas in BibTeX files are OK. A formula in field 'note': $c^2 = a^2 #> + b^2$. print(r, style = "html") #>

Francois R (2014). #> bibtex: bibtex parser. #> R package version 0.4.0. #>

#> #>

Boshnakov GN, Putman C (2020). #> rbibutils: Convert Between Bibliography Formats. #> https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=rbibutils. #>

#> #>

Murdoch D (2010). #> “Parsing Rd files.” #> https://developer.r-project.org/parseRd.pdf. #>

#> #>

Wickham H, Hester J, Chang W (2018). #> devtools: Tools to Make Developing R Packages Easier. #> R package version 1.13.5, https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=devtools. #>

#> #>

ZZZ A (2018). #> “A relation between several fundamental constants: $e^i\pi=-1$.” #> A non-existent journal with the formula $L_2$ in its name.. #> This reference does not exist. It is a test/demo that simple formulas in BibTeX files are OK. A formula in field 'note': $c^2 = a^2 + b^2$. #>

## Bib from base R packages are disabled in Rdpack v2 (notify the ## maintainer of Rdpack or raise an issue on github if you wish this back). ## ## b <- get_bibentries(package = "stats") ## print(b[[1]], style = "R") ## print(b[[1]], style = "citation") ## here the url field contains percent encoding fn_url <- system.file("examples", "url_with_percents.bib", package = "Rdpack") u <- get_bibentries(bibfile = fn_url) ## the links produced by all of the following are valid ## and can be put in a browser print(u, style = "html") #>

Boshnakov GN (2018). #> “Dummy example of URL with percents.” #> Example bibtex file, 51, 1–1. #> https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib. #>

print(u, style = "bibtex") #> @Article{urlWithPercents, #> author = {Georgi N. Boshnakov}, #> title = {Dummy example of {URL} with percents}, #> volume = {51}, #> url = {https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib}, #> journal = {Example bibtex file}, #> year = {2018}, #> pages = {1--1}, #> } print(u, style = "R") #> bibentry(bibtype = "Article", #> key = "urlWithPercents", #> author = person(given = c("Georgi", "N."), #> family = "Boshnakov"), #> title = "Dummy example of {URL} with percents", #> volume = "51", #> url = "https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib", #> journal = "Example bibtex file", #> year = "2018", #> pages = "1--1") print(u, style = "text") #> Boshnakov GN (2018). “Dummy example of URL with percents.” _Example #> bibtex file_, *51*, 1-1. https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib>. print(u, style = "citation") #> #> Boshnakov GN (2018). “Dummy example of URL with percents.” _Example #> bibtex file_, *51*, 1-1. https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib>. #> #> A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is #> #> @Article{urlWithPercents, #> author = {Georgi N. Boshnakov}, #> title = {Dummy example of {URL} with percents}, #> volume = {51}, #> url = {https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib}, #> journal = {Example bibtex file}, #> year = {2018}, #> pages = {1--1}, #> } #> ## The link here contains escapes but when put in a LaTeX document ## which uses the JSS style it generates correct clickable link, ## (see Details section) print(u, style = "latex") #> Boshnakov GN (2018). #> ``Dummy example of URL with percents.'' #> \emph{Example bibtex file}, \bold{51}, 1--1. #> \url{https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url\%20with\%20percents.bib}. ## here the journal field contains percent encoding fn_other <- system.file("examples", "journal_with_percents.bib", package = "Rdpack") j <- get_bibentries(bibfile = fn_url) print(j, style = "html") #>

Boshnakov GN (2018). #> “Dummy example of URL with percents.” #> Example bibtex file, 51, 1–1. #> https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib. #>

print(j, style = "bibtex") #> @Article{urlWithPercents, #> author = {Georgi N. Boshnakov}, #> title = {Dummy example of {URL} with percents}, #> volume = {51}, #> url = {https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib}, #> journal = {Example bibtex file}, #> year = {2018}, #> pages = {1--1}, #> } print(j, style = "R") #> bibentry(bibtype = "Article", #> key = "urlWithPercents", #> author = person(given = c("Georgi", "N."), #> family = "Boshnakov"), #> title = "Dummy example of {URL} with percents", #> volume = "51", #> url = "https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib", #> journal = "Example bibtex file", #> year = "2018", #> pages = "1--1") print(j, style = "text") #> Boshnakov GN (2018). “Dummy example of URL with percents.” _Example #> bibtex file_, *51*, 1-1. https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib>. print(j, style = "citation") #> #> Boshnakov GN (2018). “Dummy example of URL with percents.” _Example #> bibtex file_, *51*, 1-1. https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib>. #> #> A BibTeX entry for LaTeX users is #> #> @Article{urlWithPercents, #> author = {Georgi N. Boshnakov}, #> title = {Dummy example of {URL} with percents}, #> volume = {51}, #> url = {https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url%20with%20percents.bib}, #> journal = {Example bibtex file}, #> year = {2018}, #> pages = {1--1}, #> } #> print(j, style = "latex") #> Boshnakov GN (2018). #> ``Dummy example of URL with percents.'' #> \emph{Example bibtex file}, \bold{51}, 1--1. #> \url{https://github.com/GeoBosh/zzfiles/blob/master/url\%20with\%20percents.bib}.

title:
Produce the textual form of the  signatures of available methods for
  an S4 generic function — get_sig_text
code: ## load another package with some S4 methods ("methods" is already loaded) require("stats4")   rdo <- Rdo_fetch("show", package = "methods") ## alternatively: #fn <- help("show-methods", package = "methods") #rdo <- utils:::.getHelpFile(fn)  ## this will find all methods for "show" in currently loaded packages ## (print only some of them) head(get_sig_text(rdo)) #> [1] "signature(object = \"ANY\")"                       #> [2] "signature(object = \"MethodDefinition\")"          #> [3] "signature(object = \"MethodDefinitionWithTrace\")" #> [4] "signature(object = \"MethodSelectionReport\")"     #> [5] "signature(object = \"MethodWithNext\")"            #> [6] "signature(object = \"MethodWithNextWithTrace\")"    ## this will select only the ones from package "stats4" get_sig_text(rdo, package = "stats4") #> [1] "signature(object = \"mle\")"         "signature(object = \"summary.mle\")"  ## this is also fine (interactively) but need to choose ## the appropriate element of "fn" if length(fn) > 1 #fn <- help("show-methods")  ## this finds nothing #fn <- help("logLik-methods", package = "methods") #fn Rdo_fetch("logLik-methods", package = "methods") #> NULL  ## this does #fn <- help("logLik-methods", package = "stats4") #rdo <- utils:::.getHelpFile(fn) rdo2 <- Rdo_fetch("logLik-methods", package = "stats4")  get_sig_text(rdo2) #> [1] "signature(object = \"ANY\")" "signature(object = \"mle\")" get_sig_text(rdo2, package = "stats4") #> [1] "signature(object = \"ANY\")" "signature(object = \"mle\")"  ## only default method defined ## using this: setGeneric("f1", function(x, y){NULL}) #> [1] "f1" ## since the following gives error in pkgdown: #f1 <- function(x, y){NULL} #setGeneric("f1")  fn <- tempfile()  reprompt("f1", filename = fn) #> Rd source not supplied, looking for installed documentation. #> Rd source not supplied and installed documentation not found. #> Trying a 'prompt' function to generate documentation for the object. #> 	success: documentation generated using a 'prompt' function. #> 	The Rd content was written to file  /var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/file7a84632399c  #> [1] "/var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/file7a84632399c" rdo <- tools::parse_Rd(fn) get_sig_text(rdo) #> [1] "signature(x = \"ANY\")"  setClass("aRdpack") setClass("bRdpack")  ## several methods defined setGeneric("f4", function(x, y){NULL}) #> [1] "f4" setMethod("f4", c("numeric", "numeric"), function(x, y){NULL}) setMethod("f4", c("aRdpack", "numeric"), function(x, y){NULL}) setMethod("f4", c("bRdpack", "numeric"), function(x, y){NULL}) setMethod("f4", c("aRdpack", "bRdpack"), function(x, y){NULL})  reprompt("f4", filename = fn) #> Rd source not supplied, looking for installed documentation. #> Rd source not supplied and installed documentation not found. #> Trying a 'prompt' function to generate documentation for the object. #> 	success: documentation generated using a 'prompt' function. #> 	The Rd content was written to file  /var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/file7a84632399c  #> [1] "/var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/file7a84632399c" rdo <- tools::parse_Rd(fn) get_sig_text(rdo) #> [1] "signature(x = \"ANY\", y = \"ANY\")"         #> [2] "signature(x = \"aRdpack\", y = \"bRdpack\")" #> [3] "signature(x = \"aRdpack\", y = \"numeric\")" #> [4] "signature(x = \"bRdpack\", y = \"numeric\")" #> [5] "signature(x = \"numeric\", y = \"numeric\")"  unlink(fn)

title: Insert references cited in packages — insert_all_ref

Argument refs two-column character matrix.  first   column specifies bibtex keys.  specify one key   single element, separate commas. second column specifies   package look keys. key equal "*" requests keys corresponding package. insert_all_ref drops duplicated keys, collects references,   converts Rd textual representation inclusion Rd   documentation files. refs can cached environment. internal use   documented.

Boshnakov, Chris Putman (2020). #> \emph{rbibutils: Convert Between Bibliography Formats}. #> \url{https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=rbibutils}.\cr\cr Romain Francois (2014). #> \emph{bibtex: bibtex parser}. #> R package version 0.4.0.\cr\cr Duncan Murdoch (2010). #> \dQuote{Parsing Rd files.} #> \url{https://developer.r-project.org/parseRd.pdf}.\cr\cr Hadley Wickham, Jim Hester, Winston Chang (2018). #> \emph{devtools: Tools to Make Developing R Packages Easier}. #> R package version 1.13.5, \url{https://CRAN.R-project.org/package=devtools}.\cr\cr A. ZZZ (2018). #> \dQuote{A relation between several fundamental constants: \eqn{e^{i\pi}=-1}.} #> \emph{A non-existent journal with the formula \eqn{L_2} in its name.}. #> This reference does not exist. title: Insert bibtex references in Rd and roxygen2 documentation — insert_ref
text: insert_ref extracts bibliograhic reference bibtex   file, converts Rd format returns single string   embedded newline characters. workhorse provided   mechanism users even need know   insert_ref. Package Rdpack provides several Rd macros inserting   references citations documentation package. macros   work , manually written Rd files roxygen2   documentation chunks. macros look references file   "REFERENCES.bib" root installation directory   package. package development mode   devtools, "inst/REFERENCES.bib" development   directory package checked first. See also   get_bibentries note direct calls   insert_ref() can specify different file, filename   places looked fixed Rd macros. description assumes Rdpack added file   DESCRIPTION, described Rdpack-package vignette   "Inserting_bibtex_references". Rd macros put   text documentation sources (‘Rd’ files ‘roxygen2’   chunks).

title: Insert bibtex references in Rd and roxygen2 documentation — insert_ref
text: \insertRef{key}{package} inserts reference bibtex key     key file "REFERENCES.bib" package     package. Argument ‘package’ can installed R     package, necessarily one documentation object, long     contains file "REFERENCES.bib" root     installation directory.  references partially processed     package built. References inserted \insertRef appear place     macro put, usually dedicated references section     (\references Rd files, @references roxygen     chunks). example, section ‘References’ help page shows     (among things)) rendered results following lines     Rd source file: roxygen2 documentation chunk might look like : first reference label Rpackage:rbibutils taken     file "REFERENCES.bib" package Rdpack. third     reference file "REFERENCES.bib" package     rbibutils. details see vignette "Inserting_bibtex_references".
code: \insertRef{Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack}              \insertRef{parseRd}{Rdpack}                  \insertRef{bibutils6.10}{rbibutils} #' @references         #' \insertRef{Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack}         #'          #' \insertRef{parseRd}{Rdpack}         #'          #' \insertRef{bibutils6.10}{rbibutils}

title: Insert bibtex references in Rd and roxygen2 documentation — insert_ref
text: \insertCite{key}{package} cites key records use     \insertAllCited, see . key can contain     keys separated commas.  default citations parenthesised     (Murdoch 2010) .  get textual citations, like     Murdoch (2010) , put string ;textual     end key. references last two sentences     produced \insertCite{parseRd}{Rdpack}     \insertCite{parseRd;textual}{Rdpack}, respectively.      also works several citations, e.g.     \insertCite{parseRd,Rpackage:rbibutils;textual}{Rdpack}     produces: Murdoch (2010); Boshnakov Putman (2020) . mix citations text, ‘see also’     ‘chapter 3’, write list keys free text, starting     symbol @ prefixing key .      @ symbol appear output. example,     following code produces:  parenthesised form, adding ;nobrackets end     list keys causes enclosing parentheses dropped.     useful wish use markup text surrounding     references. example, gives: (see also  Murdoch 2010; Boshnakov Putman 2020 ).     Without ‘;nobrackets’ result       (see also  (Murdoch 2010; Boshnakov Putman 2020) ).
code: \insertCite{@see also @parseRd and @Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack},              \insertCite{@see also @parseRd; @Rpackage:rbibutils}{Rdpack},              \insertCite{@see also @parseRd and @Rpackage:rbibutils;textual}{Rdpack}. (\emph{see also}  \insertCite{@@parseRd; @Rpackage:rbibutils;nobrackets}{Rdpack}).

title: Make bibtex references for vignettes — makeVignetteReference
text: package character string, name installed package. vig integer number character string identifying vignette. verbose TRUE, print references Bibtex format. title character string, title vignette, see Details. author character string, title vignette, see Details. type character string, type vignette,     "pdf" "html". Currently ignored. bibtype character string, Bibtex type reference,     defaults "Article". key character string specifying key Bibtex entry.     missing, suitable key generated automatically. ... arguments passed vigbib() makeVignetteReference().

title: Make bibtex references for vignettes — makeVignetteReference
text: vigbib() generates Bibtex references vignettes   package. makeVignetteReference() produces Bibtex entry   particular vignette. seems standard way cite vignettes R packages.   vignettes complete journal papers (notably   Journal Statistical Software), authors usually   prefer papers cited, rather vignette. case,   consulting output citation("a_package") best   starting point. vignette extended substantially   paper published, cite . many cases sufficient give command opens   vignette, e.g.: vignette("Inserting_bibtex_references", package = "Rdpack"). makeVignetteReference() makes Bibtex entry one   vignette. looks available vignettes using   vignette(package=package). Argument vig can   character string identifying vignette name   used call vignette(). can also integer,   identifying vignette index (order   vignettes returned vignette()). default first   vignette returned. vig suitable, suitable list   alternatives printed. vigbib() sufficient give name package.   accepts arguments makeVignetteReference() except   vig (actually, supplying vig equivallent calling   makeVignetteReference() directly). remaining arguments can used overwrite automatically   generated entries. example, vignette authors may   package authors.

title: Make bibtex references for vignettes — makeVignetteReference

title: Make bibtex references for vignettes — makeVignetteReference
text: Georgi N. Boshnakov

title: Make bibtex references for vignettes — makeVignetteReference
code: ## NOTE (2020-01-21): the following examples work fine, but are not ##   rendered correctly by pkgdown::build_site(), so there may be errors ##   on the site produced by it, https://geobosh.github.io/Rdpack/.  vigbib("Rdpack") #> No vignettes found in package  Rdpack  makeVignetteReference("Rdpack", vig = 1) #> Error in makeVignetteReference("Rdpack", vig = 1): not ready yet, should return all vigs in the package. makeVignetteReference("Rdpack", vig = "Inserting_bibtex_references") #> Error in makeVignetteReference("Rdpack", vig = "Inserting_bibtex_references"): 'vig' must (partially) match one of: #> 	1  #>  #> 	0  #> Alternatively, 'vig' can be the index printed in front of the name above. ## the first few characters of the name suffice: makeVignetteReference("Rdpack", vig = "Inserting_bib") #> Error in makeVignetteReference("Rdpack", vig = "Inserting_bib"): 'vig' must (partially) match one of: #> 	1  #>  #> 	0  #> Alternatively, 'vig' can be the index printed in front of the name above.  ## this gives an error but also prints the available vignettes: ## makeVignetteReference("Matrix", vig = "NoSuchVignette")  vigbib("utils") #> @Article{vigutils:Sweave, #>   title = {Sweave User Manual}, #>   author = {R Core Team and contributors worldwide}, #>   journal = {URL https://CRAN.R-Project.org. Vignette included in R package utils (Part of R 4.1.2)}, #>   year = {2021}, #>   publisher = {CRAN}, #>   url = {https://CRAN.R-Project.org}, #> } makeVignetteReference("utils", vig = 1) #> @Article{vigutils:Sweave, #>   title = {Sweave User Manual}, #>   author = {R Core Team and contributors worldwide}, #>   journal = {URL https://CRAN.R-Project.org. Vignette included in R package utils (Part of R 4.1.2)}, #>   year = {2021}, #>   publisher = {CRAN}, #>   url = {https://CRAN.R-Project.org}, #> } #>  #> Team RC, worldwide c (2021). “Sweave User Manual.” _URL #> https://CRAN.R-Project.org. Vignette included in R package utils (Part #> of R 4.1.2)_. <URL: https://CRAN.R-Project.org>. ## commented out since can be slow: ## high <- installed.packages(priority = "high") ## highbib <- lapply(rownames(high), function(x) try(Rdpack:::vigbib(x, verbose = FALSE)))

code: # the following creates Rd object rdo dummyfun <- function(x) x u1 <- list_Rd(name = "Dummyname", alias = "dummyfun",               title = "Dummy title", description = "Dummy description",               usage = "dummyfun(x,y)",               value = "numeric vector",               author = "A. Author",               Rd_class = TRUE ) fn <- tempfile("dummyfun", fileext = "Rd") reprompt(dummyfun, filename = fn) #> Rd source not supplied, looking for installed documentation. #> Rd source not supplied and installed documentation not found. #> Trying a 'prompt' function to generate documentation for the object. #> Error in reprompt(dummyfun, filename = fn): unsuccessful attempt to create Rd doc. using a 'prompt' function. rdo <- tools::parse_Rd(fn) #> Warning: cannot open file '/var/folders/24/8k48jl6d249_n_qfxwsl6xvm0000gn/T//RtmpT5bL33/dummyfun7a81a74debaRd': No such file or directory #> Error in file(con, "r"): cannot open the connection  # let's prepare a new item rd <- "\\item{...}{further arguments to be passed on.}" newarg <- parse_Rdtext(rd, section = "\\arguments")  # now append 'newarg' to the arguments section of rdo iarg <- which(tools:::RdTags(rdo) == "\\arguments") #> Error in lapply(Rd, attr, "Rd_tag"): object 'rdo' not found rdoa <- append_to_Rd_list(rdo, newarg, iarg) #> Error in structure(c(rdo[[pos]], x), Rd_tag = attr(rdo[[pos]], "Rd_tag")): object 'rdo' not found  Rdo_show(rdoa) #> Error in prepare_Rd(Rd, defines = defines, stages = stages, fragment = fragment,     ...): object 'rdoa' not found  # for arguments and other frequent tasks, there are specialised functions dots <- paste0("\\", "dots") rdob <- Rdo_append_argument(rdo, dots, "further arguments to be passed on.") #> Error in Rdo_modify(rdo, wrk, create = TRUE): object 'rdo' not found  Rdo_show(reprompt(rdob, filename = fn)) #> Error in reprompt(rdob, filename = fn): object 'rdob' not found  unlink(fn)

text: get_usage() takes function object, name one,   creates text suitable inclusion usage section Rd   documentation.  usage generated function object.    interactive R session, use cat() print result   copying pasting Rd documentation saving file   (otherwise, usage text contains backslashes, may appear   duplicated).  Long text wrapped two lines. example, object anonymous function, argument name compulsory.   example,         cat( get_usage(function(x = 3, y = ""){}, "f") )  get_usage() can also used insert dynamically signatures   functions located objects, environments lists,   see examples. function used infix operator, set infix = TRUE. Backticks ok, well,   promptUsage() mostly internal use. like   get_usage() additional argument, usage, used   pass specially parsed argument list class "f_usage",   produced functions Rdpack. particular   generated previous call get_usage().
code: cat(get_usage(lm)) ##: lm(formula, data, subset, weights, na.action, method = "qr",  ##:    model = TRUE, x = FALSE, y = FALSE, qr = TRUE, singular.ok = TRUE,  ##:    contrasts = NULL, offset, \dots) cat(get_usage(summary.lm)) ##: summary.lm(object, correlation = FALSE, symbolic.cor = FALSE, \dots) cat(get_usage(summary.lm, name = "summary")) ##: summary(object, correlation = FALSE, symbolic.cor = FALSE, \dots) cat(get_usage(summary.lm, "summary", S3class = "lm")) ##: \method{summary}{lm}(object, correlation = FALSE, symbolic.cor = FALSE, \dots) get_usage("+", infix = TRUE) ##: [1] "e1 + e2" get_usage("%in%", infix = TRUE) ##: [1] "x %in% table" op <- "+" get_usage(op, infix = TRUE) ##: [1] "e1 + e2" get_usage(`+`, infix = TRUE) ##: [1] "e1 + e2" op <- `+` get_usage(op, infix = TRUE) ##: [1] "e1 op e2" op <- `+` get_usage(eval(op), name = "+", infix = TRUE) ##: [1] "e1 + e2"

title: Generate usage text for functions and methods — promptUsage
code: u <- get_usage(lm)    # a long usage text cat(u) #> lm(formula, data, subset, weights, na.action, method = "qr",  #>    model = TRUE, x = FALSE, y = FALSE, qr = TRUE, singular.ok = TRUE,  #>    contrasts = NULL, offset, \dots)  # if there are additional arguments in S3 methods, # use names of the functions, not the objects, e.g. get_usage("droplevels", S3class = "data.frame") #>                                                            droplevels  #> "\\method{droplevels}{data.frame}(x, except = NULL, exclude, \\dots)"  get_usage(name = "droplevels", S3class = "data.frame") #>                                                            droplevels  #> "\\method{droplevels}{data.frame}(x, except = NULL, exclude, \\dots)"  # (both give "\method{droplevels}{data.frame}(x, except = NULL, \dots)")  # but this gives the args of the generic:  "\method{droplevels}{data.frame}(x, \dots)" get_usage(droplevels, S3class = "data.frame") #>                                    droplevels  #> "\\method{droplevels}{data.frame}(x, \\dots)"   ## a list containing some functions summaries <- list(xbar = function(x) mean(x), rho = function(x, y) cor(x,y)) get_usage(summaries$xbar, name = "xbar") #>      xbar  #> "xbar(x)"  get_usage(summaries$rho, name = "rho") #>         rho  #> "rho(x, y)"   ## functions in an environment esummaries <- list2env(summaries) get_usage(esummaries$xbar, name = "xbar") #>      xbar  #> "xbar(x)"  get_usage(esummaries$rho, name = "rho") #>         rho  #> "rho(x, y)"

title: Update the documentation of a topic — reprompt
code:
## note: usage of reprompt() is simple.  the examples below are bulky ##       because they simulate various usage scenarios with commands, ##       while in normal usage they would be due to editing.  ## change to a temporary directory to avoid clogging up user's cur_wd <- getwd() tmpdir <- tempdir() setwd(tmpdir)  ## as for prompt() the default is to save in current dir as "seq.Rd". ## the argument here is a function, reprompt finds its doc and ## updates all objects described along with `seq'. ## (In this case there is nothing to update, we have not changed `seq'.)  fnseq <- reprompt(seq) #> Rd source not supplied, looking for installed documentation. #> Installed documentation found, processing it... #> 	The Rd content was written to file  seq.Rd   ## let's parse the saved Rd file (the filename is returned by reprompt) rdoseq <- tools::parse_Rd(fnseq)   # parse fnseq to see the result. Rdo_show(rdoseq)  ## we replace usage statements with wrong ones for illustration. ## (note there is an S3 method along with the functions) dummy_usage <- char2Rdpiece(paste("seq()", "\method{seq}{default}()",                    "seq.int()", "seq_along()", "seq_len()", sep="
"),                    "usage") rdoseq_dummy <- Rdo_replace_section(rdoseq, dummy_usage) Rdo_show(rdoseq_dummy)  # usage statements are wrong  reprompt(rdoseq_dummy, file = "seqA.Rd") #> Processing the Rd object... #> 	The Rd content was written to file  seqA.Rd  #> [1] "seqA.Rd" Rdo_show(tools::parse_Rd("seqA.Rd"))  # usage ok after reprompt  ## define function myseq()  myseq <- function(from, to, x){     if(to < 0) {         seq(from = from, to = length(x) + to)     } else seq(from, to) }  ## we wish to describe  myseq() along with seq(); ##    it is sufficient to put myseq() in the usage section ##    and let reprompt() do the rest rdo2 <- Rdo_modify_simple(rdoseq, "myseq()", "usage") reprompt(rdo2, file = "seqB.Rd")  # updates usage of myseq #> Processing the Rd object... #> 	The Rd content was written to file  seqB.Rd  #> [1] "seqB.Rd"  ## show the rendered result: Rdo_show(tools::parse_Rd("seqB.Rd"))  ## Run this if you wish to see the Rd file: ##   file.show("seqB.Rd")  reprompt(infile = "seq.Rd", filename = "seq2.Rd") #>  #> Parsing the Rd documentation in file seq.Rd ... #> 	The Rd content was written to file  seq2.Rd  #> [1] "seq2.Rd" reprompt(infile = "seq2.Rd", filename = "seq3.Rd") #>  #> Parsing the Rd documentation in file seq2.Rd ... #> 	The Rd content was written to file  seq3.Rd  #> [1] "seq3.Rd"  ## Rd objects for installed help may need some tidying for human editing. #hseq_inst <- help("seq") #rdo <- utils:::.getHelpFile(hseq_inst) rdo <- Rdo_fetch("seq", "base") rdo #> List of 16 #>  $ :List of 1 #>   ..$ : chr "Sequence Generation" #>   .. ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "TEXT" #>   .. ..- attr(*, "srcref")= 'srcref' int [1:6] 7 8 7 26 8 26 #>   .. .. ..- attr(*, "srcfile")=Class 'srcfile' <environment: 0x7f7f7e8b8630>  #>   ..- attr(*, "Rd_tag")= chr "\title" #>   ..- attr(*, "srcref")= 'srcref' int [1:6] 7 1 7 27 1 27 #>   .. ..- attr(*, "srcfile")=Class 'srcfile' <environment: 0x7f7f7e8b8630>  #>  $ :List of 1 #>   ..$ : chr "seq"
